Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(2) Summary

API security is not fundamentally different from general business security concerns: It is about how to balance the ease of access and use, and the risk of attacks and accidental misuse. Treating APIs strategically means to have policies and tooling in place that can be places around individual APIs, or some API perimeters. These policies and tooling will have to support the traditional security functions of identification, authentication, authorization, and encryption.

Introduction Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(4) Security Matters

  • Security is more than securing against external attackers
  • Security generally aims at identifying and mitigating risks
  • APIs add security surfaces that don't exist in integrated monoliths
    • Balancing API benefits and risks requires a lot of context
    • Microservices with their API focus make this problem harder
  • Security needs a lot of real-time data to be effective


Introduction Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(5) Internal Attackers

  • Service interdependencies make problems harder to locate
  • Misbehaving applications can become internal DoS attackers
  • Monitoring and situational awareness are essential
  • Security is just another facet in MSA's automation focus

Identification Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(7) Identification

  • Identity is required for any non-anonymous communications
    • groups can have an identity (facebook members see more than non-members)
    • pseudonyms are hidden identities (the real identity is not visible)
    • personal identity should be tied to a person itself
  • Proof of Identity is important for any privileged operation
    • Signatures and seals are traditional ways
    • Traditional ways are mostly protected by law (but not really safe)
    • More modern ways often include technical methods for Authentication [Authentication (1)]
  • Client identity on the Web can be bound in three ways:
    1. Computer (most of the time identified by an IP address)
    2. Browser (in the form of a stored cookie)
    3. User (identified through some authentication method [Authentication (1)])

Authentication Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(9) Authentication

  • Authentication is the process of verifying an identity
    • The weakest form of authentication is simply trust
    • Legal consequences can make it more risky to falsify authentication
    • Technical measures should make it hard to impossible to falsify authentication
  • Authentication on the Web comes in many different flavors
    • Implicitly by accessing a server from some IP address range
    • Presenting a cookie from a previous formal authentication
    • Presenting a password as a proof of identity
    • Proving that you are owning additional authentication hardware (often PIN [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_identification_number]-enabled)
  • Risk and potential damage should justify authentication methods


Authentication Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(10) HTTP Access Control

  • HTTP servers can deny access [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_HTTP_status_codes#4xx_Client_Error] through access control
    • 401 Unauthorized means the resource is access controlled
    • 403 Forbidden means the resource is inaccessible
    • 405 Method Not Allowed signals a request using the wrong request method
  • Two different approaches to unauthorized access are possible
    • Repeat the HTTP request with the proper authentication credentials
    • Redirect to a authentication flow and establish an authenticated session


Authentication Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(11) HTTP Authentication



Authentication Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(12) Basic HTTP Authentication

  • Authentication is based on authentication realms
    • A set of resources for which the authentication is required
    • An opaque name which is used to signal which login is required
    • Username/password often is specific for a given realm
  • Users supply username and password through the client
    • Sent as Base64 [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64] encoded username:password string
    • Username and password are not transmitted securely [http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=base64+decoder]
    • Basic authentication should always use HTTPS [Encryption (1)]
  • Authorization is handled on the server side
    HTTP/1.0 401 Unauthorized
WWW-Authenticate: Basic realm="SokEvo"
     [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_access_authentication]
    GET /private/index.html HTTP/1.0
Authorization: Basic QWxhZGRpbjpvcGVuIHNlc2FtZQ==
     [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_access_authentication]

Authorization Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(14) Authorization

  • Authorization is the question of allowing operations
    • Identification [Identification (1)] is necessary to identify the initiator
    • Authentication [Authentication (1)] is necessary to verify the initiator's identity
    • If the initiator is authorized, the operation can be performed
  • Web pages often are public or restricted access
    • Public web pages do not require any identification (and thus authentication)
    • Restricted access Web pages can be group pages (internal company pages)
    • Personal access is another popular scenario (email, facebook, online banking)
  • HTTP servers have well-defined ways of performing authentication [Authentication (1)]

Encryption Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(16) Secure Communications

  • Public-Key cryptography is computationally expensive
    • It is possible to encrypt all traffic using asymmetric key pairs
    • This generates considerably more load on the server side
  • Combining public-key and secret-key cryptography
    1. Check the public key for authenticity (using a certificate)
    2. Generate a key for a secret-key encryption scheme
    3. Use the public key to securely transmit the secret key
    4. Use the secret key for securely transmitting the payload
  • Combines the advantages of both methods
    • The lower complexity of secret-key algorithms
    • The ability of public-key algorithms to work without a secure channel


Encryption Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(17) HTTP and Security

  • HTTP sends clear-text messages
  • Making HTTP secure requires additional mechanisms
  • Encryption is done by a layer on top of TCP
    • Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) is the protocol layer invented by Netscape
    • Transport Layer Security (TLS) is the standardized Internet version
    • TLS adds more encryption schemes and more flexibility
  • Lower-level methods may also provide encryption
    • Virtual Private Networks (VPN) provide IP-based encryption
    • IPsec provides network interface encryption

(20) Internal/External APIs



Security Perimeters Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(21) Intranet Security

  • Internal API use may allow a less strict security policy
  • Misbehaving applications still pose a security risk
  • Behavioral security monitoring makes sense internally
    • A component that behaves like an attacker effectively is an attacker
  • Make components identifiable by always requiring access tokens


Security Perimeters Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(22) Internet Security

  • External access to APIs calls for a more strict security policy
  • Switching internal/external should be just a policy switch
  • Today's partner can be tomorrow's internal component and vice versa

Conclusions Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): API Security

(24) Automate Security

  • Treat security as an integral aspect of the architecture
  • Focus on security perimeters and associated security policies
  • Automate security infrastructure such as key management
  • Treat security as defining and applying policies
